Trish Dell
Physician. Health policy enthusiast.
Mar 9

The American Health Care Act — Is It Any Good?

The GOP rolled out with their idea for ACA replacement, and its called the ‘American Health Care Act.’ They have had more than enough time to come up with their own, unique solution to this ‘mess’ that they call ‘Obamacare’ (and I cringe every time they use that word instead of its true name). Here’s my take, from my reading of secondary sources, of what this plan will do (and won’t do)…

>>Medicaid expansion: will stay until January 1, 2020

  • No new enrollees past this date
  • Legislators are hoping that incomes will increased and enrollees will decrease anyways (so they’re basically hoping that poverty will magically solve itself)
  • Medicaid will convert to “per capita cap” where states get a lump sum for each enrollee
  • So if said enrollee gets a chronic, expensive disease cancer, there will be a cap on how much the government will pay
  • This bill also found a way to cut off Planned Parenthood funding from the federal government through Medicaid for one year (*Screams internally*)

>>Funding for vaccines will disappear and funds for other disease prevention

  • Other programs being heart disease and health-care associated infections, for example
  • This is a disaster waiting to happen

>>People with Pre-existing won’t get denied (this isn’t new)

  • So they kept something the ACA already accomplished
  • Copycats.

>>Are you 26 or under?

  • Yay for you. You still get to stay on your parents insurance.
  • No change here… copycats again.

>>No more mandate

  • The mandate which charges a penalty for no insurance will be gone
  • So all you healthy 20-something males can continue to ignore being responsible and use your hard-earned income for a kegs on the weekend
  • Here’s the catch: If you don’t have continuous coverage and then you decide to enter the insurance market, you’ll get a hefty fine (insert Nelson’s “HA-HA” meme).
  • That could some in the form of a percent premium surcharge for finally getting insurance

>>Premiums

  • Will still probably increase as a result people finally entering the insurance market when they need it (usually when they aren’t healthy)
  • But wait, there is a safety net for those who can’t afford to initially do this
  • Probably only if you rack up $50,000 in health care costs in a year
  • Some experts have proposed it will cost $1500 more than its ‘Obamacare’ counterpoint

>>Older people

  • You’ll probably get charged more (something “Obamacare” prevented)
  • The 50–60’s insurance pool is one of the highest costs, and it’ll probably increase
  • Tl;dr?… sucks to be older person with the ACHA

>>Tax credits

  • With ‘Obamacare’ (I cringe as I say that word), the tax credits were income-based, so those who earn less get more help (something that sounds logical)
  • With this plan, it is more based on age, and a tiny bit on income
  • $2,000 for those under 30, $2,500 if you’re between 30 and 40, $3,000 for those 40–50, $3,500 for those between 50–60, and $4,000 for those over 60
  • What does this mean? This sounds great?!…Wrong. Not all 25-year-olds are healthy and may have higher health care bills, so they get less tax credits than their healthy counterpart of the same age.
  • Because of these tax credits, insurers can charge older Americans five times as much. So are the tax credits really helping?…no.
  • As the director of the AARP puts it, ““You’re both jacking up the prices and giving people less of a subsidy, which is a damaging combination,.”

>>The Employer-Health-Insurance Tax

  • It’ll last for a few more years
  • Expensive health plans may be subject to more income taxes, still.
  • The government loses money by providing tax breaks on health benefits
  • What will it do?… it might raise health insurance

>>What about the tax on tanning salons?

  • It’s staying
  • Sorry, you will still get taxed for trying to give yourself skin cancer

GRADE: C-

Why?…This is average work. This is not a solve-all solution that actually betters health care access or affordability. Like that C- paper you remember writing in high school, it does not contribute to the conversation at-large. It does little to actually solve the problem. In fact, it might actually worsen health care; but its only 123 pages, so its not specific enough for us to truly know. Private insurance will still be allowed to charge premiums based on your age, health-status, gender, etc. THIS IS THE REAL PROBLEM. The problem does not end with making sure everyone gets coverage. Coverage does not equal access. And access does not equal affordability.

Legislators are hoping that a free market will cause competition and drive the market down. But since health insurance is a need (not a fun commodity to have when you feel like it), this market will not be guided by some benevolent Invisible Hand, but instead by profit margins. When you increase the amount of people in an insurance pool, that would be just swell if it did drive down cost. But health insurance is a for-profit sector, so until you eliminate a CEO’s desire to increase profits, you will not drive down costs.

My analysis is just the tip of the iceberg of the monster that is the Health Insurance Market.

So let’s just keep playing around with people’s health care until we get something right!

Sources for analysis:

· The text of the GOP plan 
· “Fake News” CNN 
· New York Times 
· Vox
